noun.description: A line on the surface of something along which it has split without breaking into separate parts.
examples: a hairline crack down the middle of the glass

noun.description: A sudden sharp or explosive noise.
A joke, typically a critical or unkind one.
An attempt to gain or achieve something.
examples: I thought I had a crack at winning

noun.description: A hard, crystalline form of cocaine broken into small pieces and smoked.

verb.description: Break or cause to break without a complete separation of the parts.
examples: the ice all over the lake had cracked
a stone cracked the headlight glass on his car

verb.description: Make or cause to make a sudden sharp or explosive sound.
examples: a shot cracked across the ridge
he cracked his whip and galloped away

verb.description: Find a solution to; decipher or interpret.
examples: a hacker cracked the codes used in Internet software
he cracked jokes which she didn't find very funny

verb.description: Decompose (hydrocarbons) by heat and pressure with or without a catalyst to produce lighter hydrocarbons, especially in oil refining.

adjective.description: Very good, especially at a specified activity or in a specified role.

phrases: Relax in a hammock, crack a book under a tree, drink iced tea on the front porch.
Most physics professors have never cracked a book on learning theory and don't understand different learning styles.
There are cheat codes to the universe, as anyone who's cracked a book on differential calculus can tell you.
It creates an immersive world that might actually lead some audience members to crack a book.
If you plan on studying only one topic, getting into IT, and then never cracking a book again, you're entering the wrong field.
we need to crack down hard on workplaces that break safety regulations
The government has cracked down on more complex tax-avoidance schemes.
Police are cracking down on crime in Bradford and have secured reductions in the rates of burglary, robbery and car crime.
Where these are not cracked down on immediately then further, and worse, anti-social behaviour usually follows.
The Executive has introduced measures through the police bill to crack down on knife culture.
origin: Old English cracian make an explosive noise; of Germanic origin; related to Dutch kraken and German krachen. crack (sense 4 of the noun) is from Irish craic entertaining conversation.
